ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned yoruba at an intermediate level, enough for survival and daily life
I have continued to expand my knowledge of the Yoruba language and its culture through this course
During this course, I gained the skill of speaking Yoruba at a height level, as well as understanding the language more
Learned more and more of Yoruba!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is very good, it allows the student to learn and speak it every day in role plays
The strength of the course is its engagement with the students and the many ways it forces you to think of things differently

Overall, the course went very well; most of us knew no Yoruba coming into the first semester of beginning Yoruba, and throughout this semester, we got more comfortable with the vocabulary from the first semester while learning some additional vocab. I think there was less new material in the second semester but we spent a lot of time reinforcing what we'd learned in the first semester which was very useful. It was also just a very fun class to be in and a supportive environment for learning. Professor Adesola is very approachable and knowledgeable and provides a lot of readings/material on Canvas to supplement what we do in class. We had some problems with attendance, so I think a stricter policy about lateness to class and late work would probably help the whole class stay on track so we can learn as much as possible.

Strength: the Professor. He is a true gem, deeply invested in student learning and a patient and supportive language instructive. Extremely accessible to students and presents the complexities of the Yoruba language structure in a student-oriented, accessible manner
This course does a great job keeping everyone engaged
The course has mostly strengths. Generally, engagement is higher since students are continuing to learn a new language, and the professor facilitates this engagement!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because it is an African language that many people know and is very engaging
Yea because the teacher is fun to learn from and the workload is very manageable

Absolutely. This class is really fun and we are able to learn a lot. I think that the rate of learning is definitely slower than L1, but there are new activities introduced that I think really cemented the foundation that we had built.

Definitely! This course has been among my favorite classes at Yale. The professor is very knowledgable, patient, and fun, and you can really get out as much as you put into this course. Grading is not harsh so it is not very stressful, but you have a lot of opportunities to practice the language and all the resources needed to learn.
Absolutely! Especially if you are learning to Get closer to your culture!
I would recommend this course to other students who are interested in not only learning the language, but who want to understand the culture as well
Yes I would recommend this course to another student. The language is beautiful, the class engaging, and the professor is the best professor I've ever had.
